input_text:
Cost-of Living Comparison

Hi, all. First... I just wanted to say that I *did* try to post this in r/jobs, but apparently that subreddit is now private. That being said... 

I am in talks with a company out in Carmel, Indiana, which is a suburb of Indianapolis. The person who reached out to me first mentioned that starting pay out there would be $51,000. I take this with a grain of salt, but this figure seems reasonable given the industry, my credentials, and my level of experience.

I am currently in the DMV/Washington, DC metropolitan area. I'm actually in a Maryland suburb (think Rockville, Gaithersburg, Bethesda, Potomac if you're at all familiar with the area) and I am making $35,360 per year. You can probably see why I want to change jobs.

I'm any case, I am just looking for input on whether $51,000 is a fair wage (in general) out in Indiana. Meaning... How far will it go, irrespective of of what I should or should not be making in my potential new position? I did a little bit of research and it seems like the cost of living out there is about 35% less than it is where I am currently, so I'm effectively getting an even bigger raise in real terms than I am in absolute terms. It seems like $51,000 in Carmel, Indiana is about equal to $78,500 in my Maryland suburb, which would mean I'd basically more than double my salary.

Does this seem about right to you guys?
detected_biases: Anchoring, Framing Effect, Mental Accounting
reasoning_paragraph: The statement exhibits several biases. The author is anchored to the initial offer of $51,000, which they consider reasonable, and then proceed to validate it through their own research. This anchoring effect influences their perception of the salary as fair. Additionally, the framing effect is present as the author presents the potential salary increase in a positive light, emphasizing that $51,000 in Carmel, Indiana is equivalent to $78,500 in their current location, which creates a more favorable impression. Furthermore, the author is engaging in mental accounting by effectively treating the potential salary increase as a windfall, focusing on the increased purchasing power in the new location rather than evaluating the salary in isolation.
bias_summary: The user tends to rely on initial information and frame their financial decisions in a way that emphasizes potential gains, while also mentally accounting for their finances in a manner that highlights favorable outcomes.

input_text:
Cash Flow & Budgeting Question - Is It Time for a Credit Card?

I am getting ready to move out of state for a new job I start in May and I'll be making significantly more than I am now. However, all of my main expenses are very much "front loaded" at the beginning of the month and that will make it difficult to afford rent all at once. My monthly budget is as follows:

\- Gross Pay: $4,250

\- Taxes: $877.08

\- Pretax Medical/Dental/Vision Premiums: $337

\- Net Pay: $3,035.92

This means I'll be bringing home about $1,517.96 per paycheck. At the beginning of the month, I anticipate my expenses to be the following:

\- Rent: $1,215

\- Renter's Insurance: $15

\- Auto Loan: $313

\- Roth 401k: $127.50

\- Auto Insurance: $87

\- Internet/WiFi: $40

\- Electric: $85

\- Water/Sewer: $30

\- Mobile Phone: $110

\- Food: $175

That puts me $680 in the negative. When I get paid again, I will net the difference: $1517.96-$680 =$837.96. That will leave me to pay the following:

\- Roth 401k: $127.50

\- Food: $175

That will leave me with $535.46 to save, invest, buy furniture, eat out more, go out on dates (God willing), etc.

As you can see, I'll be making more than enough to cover all my monthly expenses. I just have a cash flow problem. How would you guys recommend I make up the ($680) I'm left with at the end of the first paycheck before I get my next one? I'm pretty against credit cards, but I don't really see any other way around it. There's nothing I can cut out of my budget that will save $680. So what should I do? Get a credit card? I should be able to qualify easily since my FICO 8 is 752.
detected_biases: Loss Aversion, Present Bias, Sunk Cost Fallacy, Framing Effect
reasoning_paragraph: The individual is facing a cash flow problem due to the front-loaded expenses at the beginning of the month, and they are considering getting a credit card to cover the shortfall. This indicates a Present Bias, as they are prioritizing their current needs over future consequences. Additionally, their reluctance to get a credit card and preference for alternative solutions suggests Loss Aversion, as they may be fearful of potential losses or debt associated with credit cards. The individual's consideration of getting a credit card despite being "pretty against" them may also indicate a Sunk Cost Fallacy, as they may be willing to incur debt due to their initial expenses. Furthermore, the way the individual frames their expenses and income, highlighting that they "will be making more than enough to cover all my monthly expenses," suggests a Framing Effect, where they are emphasizing the positive aspects of their financial situation.
bias_summary: The user exhibits a bias towards prioritizing short-term needs over long-term consequences, with a tendency to avoid losses and frame their financial situation in a positive light.

input_text:
HYSA Advice. Should I Change from Discover?

I currently have our savings in Discover's HYSA.  It is at 3.40% APY. I love Discover (I have been with them for years) and I love their customer service.

I found SoFi recently and am intrigued by not only having a HYSA but also having a checking account that is high yield. I also love the idea of their vault system (similar to Ally's bucket system), which is something I wish Discover would do. 

If I did switch to SoFi, I would move everything.  We have several accounts at different credit unions open (we have moved a few times).  I love the idea of consolidating everything at one place. We will keep an account open locally for checks, etc. to be deposited.

Is it worth moving everything over?  Has anyone used SoFi and liked them?  Pros/cons?

Thank you!
detected_biases: Status Quo Bias, Loyalty Bias (not explicitly listed, but related to Loss Aversion), Confirmation Bias
reasoning_paragraph: The user's statement reveals a strong inclination towards maintaining their current relationship with Discover, citing their long-standing history and satisfaction with their customer service. This loyalty suggests a Status Quo Bias, where the user prefers to stick with their current situation due to a sense of comfort and familiarity. Additionally, the user is seeking validation for switching to SoFi, indicating a desire to confirm their potential decision through the experiences of others, which is a hallmark of Confirmation Bias. The user's emphasis on their love for Discover and their customer service also implies that they may be hesitant to switch due to a loss aversion-like feeling, although this isn't a perfect match.
bias_summary: The user exhibits a bias towards maintaining the status quo and seeking confirmation for potential changes, driven by loyalty and a preference for familiar relationships.

input_text:
Is It Worth Me Opening an FSA?

It is my work's open enrollment period.  I keep thinking about if I should set up an FSA. I've  never had one before, so bear with me and sorry for any stupid questions.  

I get two 90 days prescriptions that are not a lot- think $10 each. 

I don't wear glasses. 

I do need a crown, which will be right at $650, but I don't  want to wait a year for the FSA to get to that amount of funds. Can I put in a certain amount and then just stop funding it? 

I'm apprehensive about one in general due to the funds not rolling over at the end of the year.  I'm wondering if the extra paperwork and tax paper would be worth it.
detected_biases: Loss Aversion, Status Quo Bias, Present Bias
reasoning_paragraph: The individual is hesitant to open a Flexible Spending Account (FSA) due to concerns about the funds not rolling over at the end of the year, indicating a loss aversion bias, as they are worried about losing unused funds. Additionally, their reluctance to change their current situation (not having an FSA) and preference for maintaining the status quo suggests a Status Quo Bias. The individual's concern about waiting a year to accumulate funds for the crown and their consideration of stopping funding if needed also reveals a Present Bias, as they prioritize short-term needs over potential long-term benefits.
bias_summary: The user exhibits a cautious and risk-averse approach to financial decision-making, driven by a tendency to avoid losses, maintain the current situation, and prioritize short-term needs.

input_text:
Second Opinions on Upcoming Decisions

Hi yall! I'm on mobile, so I apologize for any typos and/or formatting issues. I'm internally struggling with some decisions regarding how best to use some funds, mainly around Roth IRAs. 

Some points before I start:

- My husband and I are both in our late 20s
- We both work full time, netting around ~67k/yr
- No kids (yet....currently TTC after an early mc)
- We own our own home in a very low COL area 
- We have two vehicles that are financed 
- No credit card debt 
- No student loans (praise the feeeze on interest that allowed us to pay everything off)
- We have approximately 6 months worth of expenses in savings, plus enough to cover our medical deductibles if need be. 

My husband has to have some extensive dental work done soon. He has an appointment with an oral surgeon in the start of 2022. We don't know exactly how expensive it will be, but I can imagine it will be upwards of 5k+. We would like to pay out of pocket for this. He is on my company's dental plan and just added his company's dental plan to have the extra coverage.   

He has also applied to go back to school for his masters.  It would be entirely online, and he would continue to work full time throughout the duration of the program. He doesn't want to rake out loans for that, and if he only takes one course a semester, I believe we could swing it. Before anyone asks: no, his employer will not pay for this (or any degree).  It's an entirely different field than what he currently does. 

I've been delving into retirement and investing.  I have a small investing account that gets $100 added every month.  I have been looking into the magic that are Roth IRAs. I would like to have us both start one and preferably max it out. 

However, I'm not sure that maxing out a Roth would be the way to go woth the upcoming expenses that we know we will have. Between school, dental work, and a potential baby, I'm just not sure it'd be the smartest decision.  I suppose I'm just looking for second opinions of what others would do in a similar situation.  

I will gladly answer any follow-up questions if you have any. 

Thank you!
detected_biases: Loss Aversion, Present Bias, Status Quo Bias, Mental Accounting
reasoning_paragraph: The individual is seeking second opinions on how to use their funds, particularly regarding Roth IRAs, while considering upcoming expenses such as dental work and potential education costs. The concern about not wanting to "rake out loans" for education and preferring to pay for dental work out-of-pocket suggests a present bias, as they prioritize short-term expenses over long-term savings. Additionally, their hesitation to max out a Roth IRA due to anticipated expenses indicates loss aversion, as they fear potential losses or financial strain. The individual's consideration of maintaining their current financial situation and not taking on additional debt also implies a status quo bias. Furthermore, their separate consideration of different expenses (dental work, education, and potential baby) and savings goals (Roth IRAs) suggests mental accounting, where they are mentally allocating funds to specific purposes.
bias_summary: The individual exhibits a cautious and short-term focused biasing behavior, prioritizing immediate expenses and maintaining their current financial situation over long-term savings and investments.

input_text:
Roth IRA of Roth 401(k)- Better Option?

Both mine and my husband's employers offer a Roth 401(k).  We currently contribute to both, matching our employer's match and then some.  I am wondering if we should open a Roth IRA through Fidelity in the start of 2022 instead of contributing to the Roth 401(k). 

Additionally, if we were to open a Roth IRA and put money into it- how much should we contribute to a regular 401(k)? 10%?  5%? Just employer match?
detected_biases: Status Quo Bias, Present Bias
reasoning_paragraph: The statement exhibits Status Quo Bias as the individual is considering a change to their current retirement savings strategy, but is hesitant and seeking validation for the switch. They are already contributing to their employer's Roth 401(k) and are wondering if they should instead open a Roth IRA, indicating a reluctance to deviate from their current course of action. Additionally, Present Bias is present as the individual is focused on the immediate action of opening a new account and allocating funds, without fully considering the long-term implications of their decision. The question about contributing to a regular 401(k) and the specific percentages (10%, 5%, or just employer match) also suggests a Present Bias, as they are prioritizing short-term decisions over long-term planning.
bias_summary: The user tends to favor maintaining their current financial situation and is prone to prioritizing short-term decisions over long-term planning, indicating a bias towards the status quo and present-day preferences.

input_text:
Fidelity Roth IRA Investments

I am going to open up a Roth IRA for myself, as well as one for my husband, in January 2022. I have been looking into managing it myself to avoid the advisory fees from Fidelity.

I am 27, husband is 28.

I am looking into doing a 75(domestic)/25(international) split between FSKAX and FTIHX, respectively. Then just hold and let grow for the next 40 or so years. 

Do I need to look into bonds yet?  When I used the Fidelity planner, it recommended 10% in bonds.  However, everywhere I've seen has said to not worry about bonds until the age of 50+.

For those that are currently using Fidelity, are these fee free?  Their website claims zero expense ratios for mutual index funds, which I'm assuming these are?

We are going to drop out 401(k) contributions to 10% of our pre-tax income, with the 10% including employer match.
detected_biases: Status Quo Bias, Confirmation Bias, Anchoring, Present Bias
reasoning_paragraph: The statement exhibits several biases. The investor's plan to hold a 75/25 split between domestic and international stocks (FSKAX and FTIHX) for 40 years suggests a Status Quo Bias, as they seem to prefer a straightforward, long-term approach with minimal adjustments. The investor also appears to be influenced by Confirmation Bias, as they mention that "everywhere I've seen" suggests not to worry about bonds until age 50+, which may be selectively seeking information that confirms their existing views. Additionally, the Fidelity planner's recommendation of 10% in bonds serves as an Anchor, influencing the investor's perception of an optimal asset allocation. Lastly, by planning to drop their 401(k) contributions to 10% of pre-tax income, the investor may be exhibiting Present Bias, prioritizing current consumption over long-term savings.
bias_summary: The investor tends to exhibit a conservative, long-term approach to investing, influenced by readily available information and a reluctance to adjust their strategy, while also prioritizing current consumption over long-term savings.

input_text:
401(k) Fund Allocations

I am 27 years old and have been with my job for almost two years. I've recently started getting more interested in investing and overall retirement.   

My company's 401(k) provider has my current retirement funds in their 2060 moderate growth fund with a 0.44% expense ratio.  That hurt my heart,  so I looked into choosing my own allocations, which I am able to do. I'm thinking about swictjing it all over to the Vanguard 500 (VFIAX) and Vanguard Developed Markets (VTMGX) on a 65/35 split, respectively.  Does that sound like a smart move? I'm also wondering if I should throw in the Vanguard real estate fund for good measure, though the VTMGX and VFIAX seem to be very well diversified on their own.
detected_biases: None
bias_summary: The user exhibits a tendency to make investment decisions based on emotional responses to fees and a desire for control, while also demonstrating overconfidence in their ability to make optimal investment choices.

input_text:
Lesson: Check Your Banking Accounts!

I'm so heartsick right now. We bank through a local credit union.  We have a regular  checking account and a HYSA @0.35% APY with quarterly dividends.  I stumbled across a page about different checking accounts.  We qualify for a checking sccount with MONTHLY dividends @ 0.40% APY. We are meeting with the bank on Friday (earliest we can do) to switch over to the new checking account.

EDIT: Today I learned. Thank you all. We will not be switching over for minimal difference.
detected_biases: Loss Aversion, Framing Effect, Present Bias
reasoning_paragraph: The user's initial enthusiasm to switch to a new checking account with a slightly higher APY and monthly dividends suggests that they are influenced by the Framing Effect, where the presentation of information (in this case, monthly vs. quarterly dividends) affects their decision. However, after learning more, they decide not to switch, indicating that they are also exhibiting Loss Aversion, as they are avoiding the potential "loss" of their current account and the hassle of switching. Additionally, their decision to not switch due to a "minimal difference" implies that they are prioritizing short-term convenience over potential long-term gains, which is a characteristic of Present Bias.
bias_summary: The user exhibits a tendency to prioritize short-term convenience and avoid potential losses, while being influenced by the framing of information, indicating a bias towards maintaining the status quo and avoiding hassle.

input_text:
HSA Fund Allocation

I have an HSA with approximately $3,700 in it. I am planning on using these funds when we eventually have a child, probably within the next year or two.  Since I will need the funds in a relatively short amount of time, should I be investing in bonds since they are safer?

No, I am no longer contributing to the HSA since I dropped the HDHP.
detected_biases: Present Bias, Status Quo Bias, Sunk Cost Fallacy
reasoning_paragraph: The statement reveals several biases. The individual is prioritizing short-term safety by considering bonds, indicating a Present Bias, as they are focusing on immediate needs over long-term growth. Additionally, the decision to stop contributing to the HSA due to dropping the HDHP suggests a Status Quo Bias, as they are maintaining their current state (not contributing) rather than exploring alternative options. Furthermore, the fact that they are no longer contributing to the HSA implies that they might be falling victim to the Sunk Cost Fallacy, as they are not considering the potential future benefits of the HSA simply because they are no longer receiving the associated benefits of the HDHP.
bias_summary: The user exhibits a tendency to prioritize short-term needs and maintain their current state, while also being influenced by past decisions, indicating a present-focused and inflexible approach to financial decision-making.

input_text:
Question About FZROX- Roth IRA

If I invest in FZROX in a Roth IRA, which is a large cap blend, do I also need to invest in mid- and small-cap funds? Or are there enough encompassed in FZROX that investing in mid and small would be redundant?
detected_biases: None
bias_summary: The investor tends to favor simplicity and is hesitant to add complexity to their investment portfolio, while also mentally compartmentalizing their investments.

input_text:
Budgeting for 2022

Next year, I am really going to buckle down on our finances and get ahead while we are able. I have a monthly and yearly budget sheet already prepared in Excel. I'm looking for some pointers, if there is more that I could be doing. 

Background:
Married couple, 27F (me), 28M
Estimated Gross Income: ~105,000
6+ months savings in a HYSA
Debt: Morgtage, 2 cars financed 
No kids, just cats, but TTC 

For 2022, I want to max out our Roth IRAs and put 10% (employer contribution included) into our respective 401(k)s. I am going to max out our 2021 contributions this weelend. Is this enough for retirement? 

My next plan is to pay off the cars. We paid off all of our student loans in August thanks to the interest freeze. We pay a little more on our mortgage a month. 

We have some updates we want to do to the house, mainly flooring. I'm estimating  5-6k for that. 

We are trying to conceive, so the absolute earliest we would have a kid is late next year.  I doubt that will happen, so I'm thinking early to mid 2023. I have funds in an HSA to cover my deductible and then some for a birth. 

I have a taxable brokerage account through M1. My plan is to take whatever isn't needed at the end of the month and put it towards that. 

Am I missing anything? Is there anything that you would do differently? 

Apologies for formatting, I'm on mobile.
detected_biases: Loss Aversion, Overconfidence, Status Quo Bias, Present Bias
reasoning_paragraph: The statement exhibits several biases. The user's emphasis on "getting ahead while we are able" and paying off debts, such as the cars, suggests Loss Aversion, as they are trying to minimize potential future losses. Their confidence in their current plan, as evident from asking if it is "enough for retirement," displays Overconfidence, as they might be underestimating the complexity of retirement planning. The user is also sticking to their current plan, such as maxing out Roth IRAs and 401(k)s, indicating Status Quo Bias. Furthermore, their focus on short-term goals, like paying off debts and updating the house, and allocating excess funds to a taxable brokerage account, reveals Present Bias, as they prioritize immediate needs over long-term goals.
bias_summary: The user exhibits a tendency to prioritize short-term financial security and stick to their current plan, while being overly confident in their ability to achieve long-term financial goals.

Regret Aversion is also present, as the individual may regret not having funds available for baby needs if they don't pay off the loans. The framing of having funds available for "daycare and other baby needs" influences the decision, illustrating the Framing Effect. Additionally, the emphasis on having funds available soon, given the possibility of pregnancy, suggests Present Bias, where the individual prioritizes short-term needs over long-term financial goals.
bias_summary: The user exhibits a bias towards prioritizing short-term financial security and avoiding potential losses, often at the expense of optimizing long-term investment returns.

input_text:
Is This a Good Plan? Moving to a Higher COL Area.

OK. I am on mobile, so apologies for any typos. 

This is sort of an info dump, so bear with me. 

My husband has the opportunity to do a lateral transfer within his company. Same benefits, same pay, which is 40k/year AFTER taxes/deductions and insurance.  I make 40k/year AFTER taxes.  Our gross income is $104k. 

Why would we move? We would be much closer to my parents, which would greatly help with childcare costs (no kids yet, but currently trying). We would also be significantly closer to my husband's mother. It's also an area that we would stay long term. We are ok with our current living situation, and do quite well here, but we definitely don't want to stay here forever.   

The area we would be moving to is a significantly higher COL than where we are now.  I'm looking preliminary at houses and I'm hard pressed to find something less than 300k (thanks, insane housing market).  Would we even be approved for a 300-350k house loan? 

We don't have any debt besides our current mortgage and two car payments ($600 total). 

Here is what I am considering.  My husband would take the job and live with my mom for maybe a month (she has okayed this and even suggested it). I continue living in our current home. My husband house shops while he is in the new area for work. Once we find a house, we then put our current place on thr market. This way, I can continue to work at my current job/job hunt, and we will only have the one morgtage since my mom won't charge my husband anything to stay there.  We are very fortunate to be able to do that. 

Is there anything, from an outsiders perspective, that I am missing? Please pick apart my situation so that we can make a well informed decision.
detected_biases: Status Quo Bias, Anchoring, Sunk Cost Fallacy, Present Bias
reasoning_paragraph: The individual appears to be exhibiting Status Quo Bias as they are hesitant to change their current living situation, despite the potential long-term benefits of the move. They mention that they "are ok with our current living situation, and do quite well here, but we definitely don't want to stay here forever," indicating a preference for maintaining the status quo. Additionally, Anchoring is present as they are fixated on the $300-350k house price, which may be influencing their perception of what they can afford. The Sunk Cost Fallacy might also be at play as they consider the potential costs of moving, but seem to be underestimating the potential benefits. Lastly, Present Bias is evident as they prioritize short-term convenience, such as having their husband stay with his mother, over potential long-term costs and benefits.
bias_summary: The individual tends to favor maintaining their current situation, is influenced by initial information, and prioritizes short-term convenience over long-term considerations, indicating a bias towards the status quo and present circumstances.

input_text:
Proceeds from a House Sale- What to Do?

I feel like I am dreaming. We were somehow able to snag one of the smallest brand new builds in an up and coming neighborhood.  The closing date is to be set next week sometime, but will be near the end of March. My husband starts his new position April 4th. 

We will be selling our current home. My *very conservative* estimate for proceeds from it will be 50k (will likely be more). I'm thinking that it may not be the wisest decision to roll all the proceeds over into the new mortgage. Our PMI is only about $60/month. 

I'm thinking about replenishing our emergency fund (which will be pretty depleted by paying for closing and down payments for this house- ~20k), maxing out our Roths (12k), and paying off our cars (~15k for both). 

Is that foolish to do? The PMI is just so darn low that I wouldn't feel bad to keep paying it for a while.  Any other ideas with what to do with the proceeds are helpful too. I have a taxable brokerage account that I could out some of the cash into as well.
detected_biases: Loss Aversion, Status Quo Bias, Framing Effect
reasoning_paragraph: The statement exhibits Loss Aversion as the homeowner is hesitant to roll over the proceeds into the new mortgage, possibly due to a fear of losing the funds or increasing the mortgage balance. Status Quo Bias is also present, as the homeowner seems inclined to maintain their current financial situation, mentioning that they "wouldn't feel bad to keep paying [PMI] for a while." Additionally, the Framing Effect is evident in how the homeowner presents the PMI as "$60/month" which seems low and manageable, making it more palatable to continue paying it.
bias_summary: The homeowner displays a cautious and conservative approach to financial decision-making, prioritizing maintaining the status quo and avoiding potential losses over exploring alternative uses for the proceeds.

input_text:
For How Much Should We Recast our Loan?

 We just purchased a home (we close on the 21st, woo!) and are putting down 5% on 360k. We are putting our current house on the market later this month and are projected to make a hefty profit, around 80k, once the dust settled and realtors have been paid.

Our lender told us that we could recast the new home loan once we sold our current house at a minimum of 10% of the remainder of the loan, plus a processing fee.

We are toying with the idea of putting down 15% to knock off the PMI, but the PMI is only $54/month.  My husband wants to out down only 10%. Would the extra 5% (18k) be worth it?
detected_biases: Loss Aversion, Anchoring, Mental Accounting
reasoning_paragraph: The statement reveals several biases. The couple is considering putting down an extra 5% ($18k) to eliminate PMI of $54/month. This decision is influenced by Loss Aversion, as they are weighing the potential loss of $18k against the perceived gain of avoiding a relatively small monthly loss ($54). Additionally, Anchoring is present as the lender's requirement of 10% for recasting the loan may be influencing their consideration of 10% and 15% down payments. Mental Accounting is also evident as they are framing the $18k as a separate consideration from the rest of their financial situation, specifically thinking about it as a distinct amount that could be "worth it" to save $54/month.
bias_summary: The user exhibits a tendency to make financial decisions based on perceived losses and gains, and is influenced by specific reference points and separate mental accounts.

input_text:
Talk to Me About Recasting a Mortgage

We closed yesterday on our new house.  We jumped the gun a bit and have not sold our current home, but we are fortunate to have been able to put down 5% for a conventional loan and pay closing costs (RIP our bank account). 

Our lender told me that we could recast the loan once we sold our house to bring the monthly payments down. We would put down an additional 15%, which would knock off PMI in addition to decrease the payments.   Is this a smart financial move?  I'm struggling to find any downsides to lowering the monthly payments.
detected_biases: Confirmation Bias, Anchoring, Status Quo Bias
reasoning_paragraph: The individual in the statement seems to be leaning towards recasting their mortgage, and in doing so, exhibits several biases. They mention that they are "struggling to find any downsides to lowering the monthly payments," which indicates a Confirmation Bias, as they appear to be seeking validation for a decision they have already somewhat made, rather than objectively weighing the pros and cons. Additionally, their initial loan terms, including the 5% down payment and associated closing costs, serve as an anchor, influencing their perception of the recasting option as a smart financial move, which is an example of Anchoring. Lastly, their inclination towards recasting the loan to simply lower monthly payments without thoroughly considering other factors may also indicate a Status Quo Bias, as they seem to prefer maintaining the current situation (lower monthly payments) over potentially exploring other financial strategies.
bias_summary: The user exhibits a biasing behavior characterized by a tendency to seek confirming information, rely on initial loan terms as a reference point, and favor maintaining the current financial situation.

input_text:
Options for Proceeds from House Sale

Offers are coming in on our house.  We have some options about what to do with the proceeds. I'm not sure which is best.  
Information:  
Proceeds from house (net): 70k (so far- we may get another offer that increases this number)  
New home mortgage is 342k. PMI is $54/month.  We put 5% down on a conventional loan (4% interest rate).  
Our only other debt is two cars (\~$17,000 remaining on both) with <4.5% interest rates.

**Option A**: Replenish our emergency fund.  We currently have about 2 months of funds.  I'd like to work back up to 6 (which we had prior to buying the house). To get back up to 6 months we would need $14,000.   
**Option B**: Pay down the house to 20% of its original price (so 15% down- $51,300).   We want this to be our forever home.  Doing this will reduce the length of our loan by 8 years, reduce the amount of interest paid over time, and knock off the PMI (which, while low, is still \~$600/year that is just gone).  
**Option C**: Pay off the cars (\~$17,000), or at least paying them down.  Monthly payments for both is $550.  
**Option D**: Max out our Roth IRAs ($12,000) and invest other proceeds into our taxable account.

Obviously, we could mix and match some of those options.  I'm really torn as to what to do.  Insights are appreciated. 

I can update with more information if it's needed.
detected_biases: Loss Aversion, Framing Effect, Mental Accounting
reasoning_paragraph: The statement exhibits Loss Aversion as the homeowner is hesitant to pay PMI ($54/month) and aims to pay down the house to 20% of its original price to avoid it, indicating a preference to avoid losses. The Framing Effect is present as the homeowner frames the options in terms of specific goals (e.g., replenishing the emergency fund to 6 months, paying down the house to 20% of its original price), which influences their decision-making. Mental Accounting is also evident as the homeowner considers segregating the proceeds into different uses (e.g., emergency fund, debt repayment, retirement savings), rather than evaluating the options based on a unified financial plan.
bias_summary: The homeowner's decision-making is influenced by a tendency to avoid losses, frame financial decisions around specific goals, and mentally account for the proceeds separately, rather than taking a holistic view of their financial situation.

input_text:
Explain Taxes to Me like I'm a Toddler...

Hi everyone.  I am confused about tax brackets and standard deductions.  

My husband and I contribute to Roth IRAs every year.  I understand the kicker with Roth funds are that they are post-tax dollars- that is, you have already paid taxes on them in the highest tax bracket.  Most people will benefit more from a traditional 401(k)/traditional IRA because they will be making more money in retirement than while they were working- therefore, deferring the taxes until retirement is beneficial.

So, getting into the meat and potatoes...

The obvious thing that you would want to do is to have enough of your taxable income lowered until you are pushed into a lower bracket.  For example, for married, filing jointly, your taxable income  must be between 20,550 and 83,500 to be in the 12% tax bracket.  **Does this include the standard deduction of $25,900?** In other words, if a couple grossed $109,000 for the year, would they be taxed at 22% or 12% (which is what bracket they would be in if they took the standard deduction)?  Or is each person taxed separately?

I'm sorry if this is coming across as dense.  I really don't understand how taxes are formulated for each person in a MFJ situation.

I hope this post makes sense!
detected_biases: None
reasoning_paragraph: The user's statement demonstrates a genuine desire to understand tax concepts, specifically tax brackets and standard deductions. They provide context by sharing their current financial situation, including their Roth IRA contributions, and clearly articulate their confusion. The user's tone is humble and inquiring, as they acknowledge the possibility that their question may seem "dense." There is no evidence of biased thinking, as they do not exhibit overconfidence, make unfounded assumptions, or selectively seek information that confirms their preconceptions.
bias_summary: The user exhibits no apparent biases in their financial decision-making, instead displaying a willingness to learn and seek clarification on tax concepts.

detected_biases: Status Quo Bias, Anchoring, Affect Heuristic
reasoning_paragraph: The statement reveals several biases. The investor's inclination towards the 2060 target date fund due to its simplicity and familiarity suggests a Status Quo Bias, as they seem to prefer the default or easiest option. Additionally, by mentioning that they are "most familiar with" these funds due to "limited research," the investor appears to be anchoring on the information they have, rather than seeking a broader range of options. The investor's hesitation about the bond allocation in the target date fund, asking if it's "too high" for someone their age, also indicates an Affect Heuristic, where their emotional response (concern about bond allocation) is influencing their decision-making process.
bias_summary: The user tends to rely on familiar and simple options, is influenced by limited information, and allows emotions to guide their investment decisions.

input_text:
My 457 is an IRA, not a 401k

As the title says, the 457 that my municipality offers is an IRA and not a 401k. I have a Roth IRA that I max out yearly, but I have not maxed it out for 2022. 

I want the tax benefits of a 457, but I also understand the importance of the Roth's tax-free growth.  

I'm thinking of doing a 50/50 split.  I'll get the tax advantage for 3k off of our income and 3k post tax.  Alternately, I could do a Roth 457 and max it out.  I'm unsure of what to do.  

Is there any reason that I shouldn't do one or the other? 

We live in a LCOL area.  My salary at the moment is paltry, but will go up in August.
detected_biases: Status Quo Bias, Mental Accounting
reasoning_paragraph: The statement reveals that the individual already has a Roth IRA that they max out yearly, and they are considering allocating funds to a 457 plan, which they believe offers tax benefits. However, they seem to be hesitant to fully commit to the 457 plan, even considering a 50/50 split between a traditional 457 and a Roth 457. This behavior suggests Status Quo Bias, as they are inclined to maintain their current financial situation and are hesitant to make a significant change, even if it might be beneficial. Additionally, Mental Accounting is present, as they are treating the 457 plan and Roth IRA as separate accounts with distinct purposes, rather than considering their overall financial goals and optimal allocation.
bias_summary: The user exhibits a tendency to maintain the status quo and mentally compartmentalize their finances, leading to indecision and a reluctance to make significant changes to their investment strategy.

input_text:

The question of whether it's worth contributing to the 457 Options with high ERs indicates that they are considering the costs, but may be inclined to maintain their current behavior (maxing out the Roth IRA) rather than adjusting their strategy to include the 457 Options, exhibiting Status Quo Bias. Additionally, the individual's focus on the current high ERs and their existing behavior suggests that they may be prioritizing short-term considerations over long-term benefits, which is a characteristic of Present Bias.
bias_summary: The user tends to favor maintaining their current financial behavior and prioritizing short-term considerations, indicating a bias towards the status quo and present-day preferences.

input_text:
Retirement Options for Married Couples

Per my last post...

My husband (28) and I (27) both have government jobs.  Both jobs have a pension, as well as a 457b. Husband has a 401(k). My workplace offers no employer match whatsoever.  My 456b options all have high expense rations, with the lowest being 0.94%.  Husband's are closer to \~0.05%.

I made \~37k.  Husband makes 72k.

Would it make sense for me (as far as retirement goes) to continue maxing out my Roth IRA (which is, at 6k, a substantial chunk of my post-tax income), and then increase my husband's 457b contributions in place of my own to avoid the high ER? He has a Roth IRA as well, but we could either lower his contributions or stop paying into his Roth altogether.

I'm aware that retirement is fungible when married.  We would essentially be bringing my entire paychecks home and just taking more out of his...so technically the same amount of money would be going into our account, right? 

We have no kids (as of now) and no debt besides a mortgage, which should be paid off in \~23 years, barring anything crazy happening.
detected_biases: Mental Accounting, Framing Effect, Status Quo Bias
reasoning_paragraph: The statement exhibits Mental Accounting, as the individual compartmentalizes their retirement savings into separate accounts, prioritizing their Roth IRA contributions over optimizing their husband's 457b plan with lower expense ratios. The Framing Effect is also present, as the individual focuses on the high expense ratios of their 457b options, which may be influencing their decision to prioritize their Roth IRA contributions. Additionally, Status Quo Bias may be at play, as the individual seems hesitant to deviate from their current savings strategy, including continuing to max out their Roth IRA, even if it may not be the most optimal choice given their financial situation.
bias_summary: The individual tends to prioritize their current savings strategy and compartmentalize their retirement accounts, potentially leading to suboptimal financial decisions.

bias_summary: The user tends to favor maintaining the current insurance plan and is influenced by the framing of the HDHP's benefits, while being cautious of potential losses.

input_text:
Should I consider selling my truck to get out from under the loan with the car market starting to level back out?

I have a 2013 Ford F-150 that I bought 2 years ago this June. I still owe about $15k on it and it has just over 180k miles. I bought it right when all used cars/trucks were sky high so that doesnâ€™t help but it is what it is. 

It is getting a new transmission this week to the tune of $6k. Kinda besides the point but I figured I throw that in. Regardless, most dealers that Iâ€™ve talked to recently said that id be around $10k on a trade in. Which obviously isnâ€™t ideal. However, with a new functioning transmission, I can probably get around $17k-$19k I think around here. Thatâ€™s what it blue books for anyway.

So my question is, should I sell right now while the market is still okay for sellers and get out from the upside down loan hopefully and get another truck that I would have positive equity in or do I just drive it into the ground?
detected_biases: Loss Aversion, Sunk Cost Fallacy, Present Bias
reasoning_paragraph: The statement exhibits Loss Aversion as the individual is hesitant to sell the truck due to being "upside down" on the loan, indicating a fear of realizing a loss. The Sunk Cost Fallacy is also present, as the individual mentions the recent $6k transmission cost, which is irrelevant to the decision of selling the truck, but is being considered. Additionally, Present Bias is evident, as the individual is prioritizing short-term relief from the loan over potentially long-term benefits of holding onto the truck or selling it later. The individual is focused on getting out of the loan and avoiding further losses, rather than making a decision based on the truck's overall value or long-term financial implications.
bias_summary: The user tends to make impulsive decisions based on short-term concerns, while being influenced by past investments and a desire to avoid losses.

input_text:
Help me decide where to allocate this money!

Help me decide where to allocate this money!

Managed to rack up about $9k of credit card debt over the last couple years from an assortment of stuff. (Bad luck, dumb purchases, interest etc) 

I made a plan about a year ago to really attack it and started giving $1000 a month to them. Managed to pay one off but still have some that total to where Iâ€™m at now which is around $9k (started with around that amount but had some emergencies and other dumb purchases) 

My last dumb purchases was to buy a Harley. I know I know. Financed it for $8k while still being able to pay every bill while having around $1000 left over every month. 

Anyway, with riding season in the thick of it, I decided that I would post my bike and see what happens. Well apparently I got a really good deal on it and a guy wants to give me $14,500 for it at the first of June. So if and when I sell it, I will be pocketing just under $7000. 

My main question is, should I give every dollar of that to my credit card debt

Or 

Keep it in my bank account and continue on my same plan that I have been doing and give $1000 a month? 

Or another route I havenâ€™t mentioned here? 

The bike is fun and a dream bike of mine, but the constant stress of having this debt above my head is getting old and so is not having really any money in my account. 

Any advice is appreciated!
detected_biases: Loss Aversion, Sunk Cost Fallacy, Present Bias
reasoning_paragraph: The user's statement reveals several biases. Firstly, Loss Aversion is evident as the user is hesitant to part with the $7000, a significant gain from selling the Harley, and is weighing the pros and cons of using it to pay off debt versus keeping it in their bank account. The Sunk Cost Fallacy is also present, as the user has already invested in the Harley and is now considering keeping the profit to recoup their initial investment, rather than using it to alleviate their debt burden. Additionally, Present Bias is apparent, as the user is prioritizing short-term gains and stress relief over long-term financial stability, evident in their desire to either spend the $7000 or keep it in their account for immediate access.
bias_summary: The user exhibits a tendency to prioritize short-term gains and stress relief over long-term financial stability, influenced by past investments and a desire to avoid loss.

input_text:
Wanting to move out for the first time, should I rent or buy?

24 Male. I make 21.50/hr which after taxes is about $2,600 a month. My only "big" bill is my truck payment of $300. The rest is miscellaneous stuff like credit card bills, and phone bill. After that, I'm basically pocketing the rest. 

With that being said, i have a great relationship with my parents and younger brother who is almost 22. They are nice enough to not charge me rent as I do stuff around the house in terms of mowing, fixing sinks, vacuuming etc. So, i have no reason to rush into moving out and they said i can stay as long as I want lol 

I love them for that but I'm to the point where I'm wanting to start my own journey. It's hard to date too lol 

I know at some point within the next few years or so I want to buy a house. So, would it be dumb to rent knowing that? Or should I go ahead a rent since I have no experience living on my own? Just to get a feel for what home ownership will feel like?
detected_biases: Status Quo Bias, Present Bias, Sunk Cost Fallacy
reasoning_paragraph: The individual in this scenario is hesitant to move out of their parents' house, not due to financial constraints, but because they have a comfortable living situation with no rent. This comfort and the benefits they provide to their family, such as doing chores, may be causing a Status Quo Bias, as they are inclined to maintain their current situation. Additionally, the fact that they can stay as long as they want may lead to a Present Bias, prioritizing short-term comfort over long-term goals, such as gaining independence and experience living on their own. The mention of not wanting to "rush into moving out" and the consideration of renting just to "get a feel" for homeownership may also indicate a Sunk Cost Fallacy, as they seem to be weighing the costs of moving out against the benefits of staying, rather than objectively evaluating the pros and cons of each option.
bias_summary: The individual exhibits a tendency to prioritize short-term comfort and maintain the status quo, while being hesitant to take on new experiences and responsibilities, indicating a bias towards maintaining their current situation.

bias_summary: The user tends to make impulsive, emotion-driven decisions, influenced by specific values and short-term desires, rather than objective evaluations of their financial situation.

input_text:
As a first time home buyer, should I consider buying this spring/summer or rent and wait to buy?

Male 25 living in the KC area. Currently live at home and have been wanting to move for a little while now. Making about $40,000 a year with no debt other than a truck loan which is around $300 a month.

Since I would be doing all this myself, income wise, I donâ€™t really want to get into a bidding war and overpay for a house thatâ€™s 45 mins from my job. And with it being my first home, I really donâ€™t want to be pressured or rushed into this decision. The county Iâ€™m in is the most populated and wealthy in the state and and even the country. 

So my main question is, and Iâ€™m sure others have had the same question.. should I just rent a place and wait a year and see how the market is doing then and continue to save for a house? Or see if I can buy something relatively soon. Like this summer. 

I donâ€™t mind renting, but my current lifestyle would be better suited with a house. And my GF agrees. But with supply so low, I donâ€™t want to settle. 

So really just looking for a discussion or your guysâ€™ opinions on the whole matter.

bias_summary: The user tends to make decisions based on short-term emotional preferences and a desire to maintain the status quo, while being averse to potential losses and uncertain outcomes.

input_text:
Should I buy this truck?

Make $2800 take home a month
$875 for rent
$150 for utilities and other expenses

I pay $300 a month currently for my truck. Problem is, itâ€™s 10 years old with 190k miles. And before you ask, yes I need a truck. I have a 23 foot camper we tow regularly in the summer to camp in. I found a 2015 F150 for 32k with 96k miles. 

I still owe about $8,300 on my current truck and will probably pay it off in a couple years. Itâ€™s starting to rust and have a few more break downs than Iâ€™d like. Which is why I have been casually looking in the first place. 

Went to test drive the truck today and itâ€™s perfect and everything I want in a truck. My monthly payment would increase $140 bucks a month to make my truck payment $440 a month. After I did all the math I would have about $1100 a month after all my monthly expenses to have for saving/investing/entertainment etc. 

I donâ€™t live an extravagant lifestyle in the slightest and really only have fishing and camping as my hobbies. Which are very cheap. 

So, would increasing my truck payment $140 a month be that bad of a thing? 

They dealer would be giving me $11,500 for mine and I would be down $3000 of my own money. So I am not financing the entire asking price. Be about $6000 down overall.
detected_biases: Sunk Cost Fallacy, Status Quo Bias, Present Bias
reasoning_paragraph: The individual is considering upgrading to a new truck, but is hesitant due to the increased monthly payment. However, they are already emotionally attached to their current truck, having owned it for 10 years and still owing $8,300 on it. This attachment is evident in their consideration of the sunk cost of still owing on their current truck and the hassle of selling it, which might be influencing their reluctance to upgrade. Additionally, they seem to be anchored to their current lifestyle and expenses, as indicated by their simple hobbies and non-extravagant lifestyle. The individual is also focused on short-term expenses, asking if increasing their truck payment by $140 a month would be "that bad of a thing," which suggests a present bias towards current expenses over long-term benefits.
bias_summary: The individual exhibits a tendency to prioritize current financial situations and emotional attachments over objective evaluations of long-term benefits, leading to potentially biased decision-making.

input_text:
Not sure which route to go with vehicle buying

I will try to sum this up as best as possible. 

25 Year old male. Was driving a 2011 Silverado 1500 which I really liked. I financed it for $14k with a payment of $260 a month. Was giving $300 a month. Was making $2800 a month

My expenses were low since I was still living at home. Left that job and accepted a new position making $2500 a month. That job didnt pan out, however, I also moved into am apartment at $875 a month and also traded in my truck for a newer one at $32k in the same week. 

Since the job did not pan out, I had to accept a job making $2000 a month while still having the $875 a month apartment and a $485 a month truck payment. So yeah, im basically treading water. 

&#x200B;

Im obviously getting rid of the truck since I really dont need that much truck. However, I do need a truck. Living in the country in the midwest, roads arent the best and we can get bad winters. On top of that, I have a 23 foot travel trailer that I pull quite a bit. Bottom line, I need a truck. 

However, as most of you know, the truck market is just nuts right now so finding a good truck for a cheaper price is almost impossible. I found one for $23k, so significantly cheaper than the one I have currently but I would obviously have to finance it. Which I am not opposed to, however, in a perfect world, my monthly payment would be super cheap. Right now, im probably looking at a mid 3's payment, which is better. 

So, not sure what real route to take. Really just seeing if I could get a good discussion going and hopefully iron out some of this. 

&#x200B;

Income: $2000 a month

No student loans

$3000 CC debt 

No other debt besides my current truck (which I will be getting ride of)

Rent: $875 a month

Everything else associated with the apartment: $150- $200 a month
detected_biases: Sunk Cost Fallacy, Status Quo Bias, Present Bias

The Sunk Cost Fallacy is evident as they mention they "obviously" need to get rid of the truck because it's not affordable with their current income, but still hesitate to let go, implying that they're holding onto it due to the significant resources already invested. The Status Quo Bias is also present as they seem to be inclined to maintain their current situation, even if it's not ideal, rather than making a change that might bring long-term benefits. Furthermore, the Present Bias is apparent as they prioritize short-term financial relief, such as lower monthly payments, over potentially more beneficial long-term financial decisions.
bias_summary: The individual exhibits a tendency to prioritize short-term financial relief and maintain the status quo, while being influenced by past investments, indicating a biased decision-making process.

input_text:

I like to work on things, have tools, hunt and fish etc. and itâ€™s always been my ultimate goal to buy a house to have my own place and especially a garage with a yard. 

The apartment isnâ€™t terrible but everyone knows the pros and cons. Some peoples personalities and lifestyles are perfectly content with apartments and since this is my first place on my own, itâ€™s definitely not bad. But itâ€™s just not me. 

So my plan is to move back in with my parents, whom I have a great relationship with, to save a ton of money. Is this a good move financially? And then once the housing market returns to somewhat normal, Iâ€™m hoping to have saved enough money for a house at that point.

Internet $50

detected_biases: Status Quo Bias, Present Bias, Sunk Cost Fallacy
reasoning_paragraph: The individual is considering moving back in with his parents to save money for a house, which indicates a willingness to revisit a previous living arrangement. However, he frames his current apartment as "not terrible" but not suitable for his lifestyle, which suggests that he is prioritizing his current preferences over potential long-term financial gains. This line of thinking reveals a Status Quo Bias, as he is inclined to revert to a familiar situation (living with parents) rather than sticking with his current arrangement. Additionally, his focus on short-term savings and immediate gratification (having a garage and yard) indicates a Present Bias, prioritizing current desires over future benefits. Lastly, his mention of having already invested in an apartment and implying that he needs to make the most of it hints at a Sunk Cost Fallacy, where he feels committed to his current situation due to past investments.
bias_summary: The individual exhibits a bias towards reverting to familiar situations, prioritizing short-term gains, and being influenced by past investments, indicating a tendency towards Status Quo Bias, Present Bias, and Sunk Cost Fallacy.

input_text:

input_text:

Since I was paying for everything (my choice), I couldnâ€™t chisel away at my CC and definitely couldnâ€™t save any money afterwards. 

Thatâ€™s the original plan. But itâ€™s only been 2 days and I am already looking to get out of parents again. I just need my own space. I didnâ€™t think it would be a big deal but damn my mom is making it tough. Love her to death but shit. 

My goal is to buy a house but it doesnâ€™t sound appealing just with the how little inventory there is and the price of what is out there for starter homes. 

Whatever route I decide to go, my GF said she would contribute half of the bills. She will be making around $75k a year and Iâ€™ll be at $47k a year. So, either one wonâ€™t be an issue. But I donâ€™t want to jump into a house that Iâ€™ll probably be over paying for. When the apartments we just got out of are really nice for a actually a decent price. Which is where Iâ€™m torn. 

I would love a house, but I loved how easy the apartment was. 

Idk, Iâ€™m just torn between the two right now. I donâ€™t mind the housing route, but I would like to take my time with it and not be rushed into anything. Iâ€™m 26 and sheâ€™s 23.

detected_biases: Status Quo Bias, Present Bias, Affect Heuristic

bias_summary: The individual exhibits a tendency to prioritize short-term comfort and familiarity, while being influenced by their emotions, leading to indecision and a bias towards maintaining the status quo.

input_text:
Wanting a motorcycle for fun but I can see saving money as well

So I drive a 2013 f150 5.0. Love the truck but itâ€™s my daily. I was just curious today at work and wondered how much I was spending in gas and I was shocked. March I spent $510 and April I spent $480. All that combined with my $400 a month payment. I was dumbfounded. 

I have been looking at a small Harley just for fun but I think I could actually save money monthly by getting one. The bike would be like $150 a month or so. And fuel would be around $20 a month. So right there, I would save a few hundred dollars or so by getting a bike and scratch the itch I have for it. Dumb idea? Or not bad?
detected_biases: Loss Aversion, Framing Effect, Mental Accounting
reasoning_paragraph: The individual is weighing the desire for a motorcycle against the practicality of saving money. They are drawn to the idea of switching to a motorcycle because it would allow them to "scratch the itch" for a fun activity while also potentially saving money. This suggests Loss Aversion, as they are motivated by the prospect of avoiding losses (high gas costs and loan payments) rather than solely focusing on gains. The Framing Effect is also present, as the individual frames the motorcycle as a way to save money, rather than considering the upfront costs of purchasing a new vehicle. Additionally, Mental Accounting is evident, as the individual is separately considering the costs of the truck (gas, loan payments) and the potential costs of the motorcycle, rather than evaluating the overall financial implications of the switch.
bias_summary: The individual tends to make financial decisions that balance emotional desires with practical considerations, often framing choices in a way that minimizes perceived losses.

input_text:
I feel trapped almost with the current state of the economy paired with my financial situation

I guess this is more of a rant than anything but I would welcome any advice. 

Will be turning 27 this August. I make $42k a year gross in a okay cost of living area in the Midwest (Kansas). There are places that are expensive but not terrible. 

Long story short.. I daily drive my 2013 F-150 40 miles a week round trip to work. I owe currently $18k on it and pay $380 a month for it. I was living in an apartment paying almost $1000 for everything associated with that. Last month my lease ended so I decided to move back home for a bit to save some money and get a game plan together. 

I also have about $6k in CC debt. Other than my truck and the CCâ€™s, thatâ€™s all my debt. 

Recently, since I got this newer better paying job, Iâ€™ve been thinking about getting a motorcycle. I have no problem with financing it but I kinda feel guilty almost wanting to get one now that Iâ€™m living back at home. But with gas being at $4.00 a gallon today, I donâ€™t think me getting 12mpg and filling up for $120 bucks, give or take, every week or so is sustainable. Thatâ€™s partly why I think a motorcycle may be good, not only for my wallet, but also my mental health. 

I donâ€™t currently have anything for ME. I just go to work, come home, eat, and go to bed. 5 days a week. I want SOMETHING, that brings me happiness. 

Again, Iâ€™m just not sure what route to take. I love my truck, and use it to fish and hunt and pull our camper in the warmer months, but damn is it costing me more than I want lol 

So, should I, continue on my current plan which is to just pay of my CCâ€™s as quickly as possibly and then just save some money until I find another apartment? 

Or

Finance a motorcycle, to save on my monthly fuel expense to put more money towards CCâ€™s so I can get those paid off quicker? While having something that brings me a lot of joy. 

So, idk, I know I kind of rambled on there but I think you guys get the idea. Just kind of in a weird spot financially and in life and would like an open discussion!
detected_biases: Loss Aversion, Present Bias, Mental Accounting, Affect Heuristic
reasoning_paragraph: The individual in the statement appears to be influenced by Loss Aversion, as they express feelings of being "trapped" and emphasize the costs associated with their current financial situation, particularly with their truck. They also exhibit Present Bias, prioritizing short-term desires, such as getting a motorcycle for enjoyment and potential fuel savings, over long-term financial goals. Mental Accounting is evident in their consideration of using a motorcycle to save on fuel expenses and allocate more funds towards credit card debt, essentially compartmentalizing their finances. Lastly, the Affect Heuristic is present, as they make decisions based on how they feel about their current situation, such as feeling guilty about wanting a motorcycle while living at home, and seeking something that brings them happiness.
bias_summary: The individual tends to prioritize short-term desires and emotional comfort over long-term financial goals, often making decisions based on feelings and present circumstances rather than objective financial considerations.

input_text:
Repair My Truck or Trade In?

Anyway, I owe $17k on it with 176k miles. Iâ€™m probably upside down about $2k-$4k depending on the day. Which I was okay with because I planned on driving it until it blew up. 

Well, I donâ€™t know for sure how much itâ€™s going to cost, but some repair codes and what the truck is doing in general has me thinking itâ€™s going to need some decent transmission work. Which is never cheap. Iâ€™m estimating between $1,500-$6,000. Again, I wonâ€™t know for sure until Wednesday. 

But that brings me to my question, if it is worst case scenario, so I trade it off and cut my losses, or just add to my upside down situation and pay to get it fixed? 

I understand that if I do get this fixed, it will probably be set of many many years. But that would pretty much put me at owing $23k on the truck that has almost 180k miles and is almost 10 years old.

detected_biases: Sunk Cost Fallacy, Loss Aversion, Status Quo Bias

Additionally, they are averse to cutting their losses, which is a manifestation of Loss Aversion. The individual's consideration of adding to their upside-down situation to fix the truck, rather than trading it in, also suggests a Status Quo Bias, where they prefer to maintain the current state of affairs rather than making a change.
bias_summary: The user exhibits a tendency to prioritize past investments and avoid losses, leading to a bias towards maintaining the status quo and avoiding decisions that would result in perceived losses.

input_text:

detected_biases: Loss Aversion, Framing Effect, Present Bias, Recency Bias
reasoning_paragraph: The statement reveals several biases. The writer's concern about not wanting to miss out on rising housing prices due to paying off student loans first indicates Loss Aversion, as they fear missing out on potential gains in the housing market. The Framing Effect is also present, as the writer frames paying off student loans as a hindrance to buying a house, rather than considering it as a form of forced savings. Additionally, the writer's emphasis on paying off loans quickly and considering using bonuses and tax refunds to accelerate repayment suggests Present Bias, as they prioritize short-term debt repayment over long-term goals like saving for a house. Lastly, Recency Bias is evident in the writer's mention of the current housing market being "ridiculous" and their FOMO (fear of missing out) about rising prices, indicating that recent events are influencing their decision-making.
bias_summary: The user exhibits a bias towards prioritizing short-term debt repayment and fear of missing out on potential market gains, influenced by recent events and a framing effect that prioritizes debt repayment over long-term savings goals.

Additionally, their emphasis on "growth and passive income" and desire for "high stable dividend stocks" for early retirement suggests an affect heuristic, where they are making decisions based on emotions (e.g., the appeal of passive income) rather than a thorough analysis. input_text:
Should I take a vacation with my family?

My family consists of my wife, myself and our 9 month old child. We live in Texas and we all live with my parents as we canâ€™t afford a place to live yet.

Last year we made about $25,000 together, and weâ€™re probably going to make about the same amount this year if not a little bit more. We currently have saved up about $2,100 and we get to add about $300 or more every month towards those savings.

Monthly expenses include groceries which is about $300 a month, car insurance $140, car payment $262 Phone bill $50, a few online service like Hulu, Disney Plus and Apple Music ~$25, and other things like gas $35-50, etc.

The only debt we currently have is our car, which is about $10,000 and one that Iâ€™m paying an extra $100 a month (on too of the $262 minimum) towards it, and plan on paying it off in about 12-18 months from now.

Anyways, she wants us to go on our first vacation on spring break next month, and she thought Branson, MO was a good place to go too, so I reserved our hotel a few weeks back and paid it off already (though it can be cancelled for free if I change my mind before then).

I have already requested that week off from my job ( and it will be paid time off ).

Now my question is, should I take my family on this trip, or should I not and keep the money we would spend there and add it to our savings?

If Iâ€™m missing and info please ask, will reply as soon as I can.
detected_biases: Sunk Cost Fallacy, Present Bias, Mental Accounting
reasoning_paragraph: The individual is hesitant to take their family on a vacation, citing their financial situation and savings goals. However, they have already invested in the vacation by reserving and paying for the hotel, and have requested paid time off from work. This suggests that the Sunk Cost Fallacy is at play, as they may feel committed to following through with the vacation plans due to the resources already invested. Additionally, the individual's focus on short-term savings goals and immediate financial concerns indicates a Present Bias, prioritizing current financial stability over enjoying a vacation with their family. Furthermore, the way they are mentally categorizing their savings and expenses, considering the vacation as a separate entity from their regular savings, suggests Mental Accounting.
bias_summary: The individual exhibits a bias towards prioritizing short-term financial gains and previously made investments, while undervaluing the potential benefits of taking a family vacation.

detected_biases: Loss Aversion, Status Quo Bias, Framing Effect
reasoning_paragraph: The individual is hesitant to purchase health insurance due to the perceived high cost of $130 a month, which translates to $1,560 a year. This suggests Loss Aversion, as he is focusing on the potential loss of money rather than the potential benefits of having health insurance. Additionally, since he and his wife have never had health insurance before, he may be exhibiting Status Quo Bias by being inclined to maintain their current situation rather than changing to a new, uncertain option. The framing of the insurance cost as "$130 a month, so $1,560 a year" may also be influencing his perception, as the Framing Effect could be making the cost seem more burdensome than if it were presented in a more neutral or positive light.
bias_summary: The individual tends to make conservative financial decisions, prioritizing avoiding losses and maintaining the status quo over exploring new options, often influenced by how information is presented.

input_text:
Moving to another city with parents

Iâ€™m 21 years old, married with a 10 month old child; all three of us live with my parents in a small pastorage owned by the church.

I work for a McDonaldâ€™s in my town ( which is one of the best jobs I could get in the past three years of job searching ) as a department manager for $9.75 an hour.

My wife is mainly a SAHM, but has a small job helping with childcare at a church and she brings in about $100 a month.

This pat year we made $25,500 and we are probably gonna make a little more than that this year.

Our current debt is our car which we still owe about $10,000 and make $372 monthly payments ($100 over the minimum). Our other expenses include about $300 a month for groceries, $50 phone bill and Car Insurance for $140.
Other misc expenses are some media services like Apple Music, Disney + and Hulu that round up to about $25 a month. Besides that the only other â€œexpenseâ€ are tithes and offerings, which is 10% tithe and 10% offerings.

Our savings is standing at about $4,500 right now.

We arenâ€™t able to afford a place to live as rent is about $700 at least in this place, and we only get to keep about $400-$500 in savings a month.

Now the main issue is that my parents are planning on leaving the church and going to leave to another city 12 hours away from here. They plan on going to make a down payment for a house this weekend in which we can all live in. This has been discussed for a while now, and we agreed on them finding a four bedroom home for all of us to live. 

I just finished talking to them and while we might not move there for another year, once the house is done in about 6 months, we must start making payments and they asked for me to start helping then too; I agreed as I donâ€™t see any way we can afford a place of our own for a few more years.

My wife hates the idea as she doesnâ€™t like my parents, and would have to leave all her family behind. I donâ€™t like it because I finally got the position I wanted after a few years and I would hate to leave after only a year of holding the position.

Like I mentioned before, I donâ€™t see any other solution, and once we move we would all have to find new jobs too, and while they may pay more an hour, K might just end up making either the same or less of what I am now.

Is there any advice anybody can give?
detected_biases: Status Quo Bias, Sunk Cost Fallacy, Present Bias
reasoning_paragraph: The statement reveals several biases. The writer seems to be exhibiting Status Quo Bias, as they are hesitant to leave their current situation, including their job and social network, even if it might be beneficial in the long run. They mention that they "finally got the position I wanted after a few years" and would hate to leave after only a year, indicating a preference for maintaining the current status quo. Additionally, the writer is influenced by the Sunk Cost Fallacy, as they consider their current job and situation as investments that would be "wasted" if they were to leave. They also exhibit Present Bias, as they prioritize their current situation and short-term concerns over potential long-term benefits of moving to a new city.
bias_summary: The user tends to prioritize maintaining their current situation and short-term stability over potential long-term benefits, indicating a bias towards the status quo and a reluctance to change.

input_text:
Employer might stop giving overtime

I'm a 22 year old that works at a franchised McDonald's as a Kitchen Department Manager making $9.75/hr, and have worked there for about 8 months so far, and was given one raise of $.75 back in December.

About a month ago when all this covid-19 scare began, almost everybody at work has had reduced hours, and when it comes to all the managers, we have had 0 scheduled overtime hours, when we usually used to get anywhere between 5 - 10 every week. My pay has never been good, but overtime always made up for it as I would always get roughly 20 - 30 overtime hours per month.

That aside, we haven't been able to meet our labor percentage goal, which is something like 21%, but now we are able to that we have less people scheduled, but I'm afraid that even when all this comes to normal, my employer will either reduce or give no more overtime to any of us. Most of the other managers don't seem to mind, they just go to work and expect to get good pay, but I'm always looking at the numbers and as of this month I am losing about $300 per month, which makes a lot of difference to me as that was almost all the savings I was getting form my job.

Ultimately my question is, when this is all over and we go back to normal, if my employer decides to give little to no overtime, should I ask for a raise, and if so how should I come to him about that? I'd probably have to ask for a raise to at least $11/ht, which seems too high for them to agree to in my opinion, but I am uncertain.
detected_biases: Loss Aversion, Present Bias, Anchoring
reasoning_paragraph: The statement exhibits Loss Aversion as the individual is highly concerned about the potential loss of overtime pay, which has been a significant contributor to their savings. This concern is driving their decision-making, as they are proactively thinking about asking for a raise to mitigate this potential loss. Present Bias is also evident, as the individual is prioritizing their current financial situation and immediate needs over long-term considerations. Additionally, Anchoring is present as the individual is referencing their current hourly wage of $9.75 and considering a raise to $11/hr, which may be influenced by their current wage and the perceived value of their role.
bias_summary: The user exhibits a loss-averse and present-focused mindset, prioritizing immediate financial concerns and anchoring on current values when considering future decisions.
